abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, having achieved its physical objectives, with
            a sustainable likelihood. The Bank performed satisfactorily,
            maintaining a project team continuity, resulting in
            consistent recommendations to the Borrower on both, physical
            and institutional components. Although project
            implementation was somehow delayed, the Borrower did project
            strong ownership, resulting in a satisfactory performance.
            Regardless of success, the key lessons show that: a) the
            presupposed acceptance by the borrower of major policy
            reforms, stemming from a technical assistance restructuring
            study, whose results were unknown at appraisal, would have
            been better acknowledged in future lending operations; b)
            the active participation of entities, not just the
            Government, in technical assistance issues, suggest a more
            effective restructuring of those sector entities, when
            supported by the entities themselves; c) approval of gas
            price increases proved valuable in conveying the right
            economic signals to consumers, improving in turn the
            beneficiary's financial situation; d) the right-of-way
            should be minimized, possibly reaching agreements prior to
            well drilling; e) load management analysis should be a
            prerequisite to field development programs; and, f)
            co-financing may be beneficial, due to the cooperation and
            information exchange among institutions.
